questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of a painless wound on her right toe. She has not sought medical care in over 5 years. She has a history of untreated hypertension. Her temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 160/100 mm Hg. A photograph of the lesion is shown. There is diffuse hyperpigmentation of the anterior shins. Probe-to-bone testing of the lesion is negative. Sensation to pinprick and light touch is decreased over the soles of the feet bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's foot lesion?

choices.text: Immune-mediated inflammation of small blood vessels
Bacterial infiltration into the bone marrow

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Incompetence of venous valves leads to chronic venous insufficiency (CVI), a condition that can cause cutaneous ulcers and hyperpigmentation of the leg. However, cutaneous ulcers due to CVI are typically painful and develop near the malleoli, whereas this patient has nontender lesions on the digit of the foot. Moreover, CVI does not cause bilaterally decreased sensation of the lower extremities.
Image Description:

Medial aspect of the right foot

An ulcer with surrounding erythema is visible on the medial malleolus of the right foot.

These findings are characteristic of venous ulcer secondary to chronic venous insufficiency.

B) CORRECT:

Chronic hyperglycemia leads to nonenzymatic glycation (NEG) of axon proteins, which causes progressive sensorimotor neuropathies, especially of the peripheral nerves. This explains why diabetic foot ulcers are typically painless. Furthermore, NEG causes autonomic neuropathy and vascular disease, both of which contribute to the formation and poor healing of diabetic foot ulcers. Patients with DM should undergo regular screening for neuropathy, which includes assessments of sensation to vibration (using a tuning fork), pressure (using a monofilament test), and pain (using a pinprick test). Strict glycemic control should be maintained in order to prevent diabetic neuropathy and other complications.

NEG of hemoglobin due to chronic hyperglycemia can be assessed by measuring HbA1c percentage. A value ≥ 6.5% is sufficient to diagnose DM, and a value of 5.7–6.4% indicates prediabetes. NEG of the glomerular basement membrane is also common and can lead to renal failure and a progressive decline in kidney function. Screening for proteinuria is therefore recommended for all patients with DM.

C) INCORRECT:

Small vessel vasculitis is seen in patients with thromboangiitis obliterans (TAO), which can manifest in late stages with cutaneous ulcers that are typically localized on the digits. However, TAO usually also manifests with intermittent claudication, Raynaud phenomenon, and/or migratory thrombophlebitis.
Image Description:

There are areas of black, necrotic tissue visible on the first toe of the right foot and the third toe of the left foot surrounded by white areas of maceration. Furthermore, the fifth toe of the left foot shows early signs of autoamputation. Massive trophic nail changes can be seen especially on the left foot. Generally, the toes of the left foot look swollen and have a livid discoloration (left more than right).

These findings are typical of gangrene, in this patient caused by thromboangiitis obliterans.

D) INCORRECT:

Peripheral arterial disease (PAD) can occur in patients with diabetes mellitus and can cause cutaneous ulcers as a late manifestation. However, lesions due to PAD are painful, whereas this patient has a history of a painless ulcer. Moreover, other characteristic features of PAD, such as intermittent claudication and diminished pulses are absent.
Image Description:

Photograph of left foot

Numerous ulcers are visible on this patient's foot.

This appearance is suggestive of ischemic ulcers in peripheral arterial disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Osteomyelitis can develop as a complication of chronic ulcers, in which skin bacteria infiltrate through the ulcer and into the bone marrow. This condition is especially common in patients with diabetes. However, this patient does not have typical features of osteomyelitis such as a positive probe-to-bone test, fever, or pain at the site of the lesion.
questions.hint: This patient has several manifestations of diabetes mellitus (DM), including a painless ulcer located at a pressure point, decreased sensation over the soles of the feet, and hyperpigmented skin (due to diabetic dermopathy).

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician because of painless swelling of his left foot for the past 4 months. The swelling was initially accompanied by redness, which has since resolved. He has not had fever or chills. He has a history of coronary artery disease, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has had 3 sexual partners over the past year and uses condoms inconsistently. His mother had rheumatoid arthritis. Current medications include clopidogrel, aspirin, metoprolol, losartan, atorvastatin, and insulin. He is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 95 kg (209 lb); BMI is 29 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Cardiovascular examination shows no abnormalities. Examination of the feet shows swelling of the left ankle with collapse of the midfoot arch and prominent malleoli. There is no redness or warmth. There is a small, dry ulcer on the left plantar surface of the second metatarsal. Monofilament testing shows decreased sensation along both feet up to the shins bilaterally. His gait is normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient's family history puts him at increased risk for rheumatoid arthritis (RA). However, RA usually manifests with inflammatory polyarthritis and is characterized by warmth, redness, and swelling in the affected joints as well as fever. Furthermore, unilateral foot involvement would be very unusual in RA, which usually affects the small hand and wrist joints.

B) INCORRECT:

Chronic osteomyelitis is a common complication of diabetic neuropathy that is often preceded by ulcer formation and can result in bony destruction due to deep bacterial infection of the bone. This patient presents with an ulcer (a common entry location for pathogens) and signs of chronic bone destruction but osteomyelitis would typically also manifest with signs of inflammation (i.e., redness, warmth, and pain).

C) INCORRECT:

This patient's history of diabetes increases his risk of developing calcium pyrophosphate arthropathy (pseudogout). However, pseudogout is characterized by acute inflammatory symptoms (e.g., redness, warmth, pain) and the feet are typically not involved.

D) INCORRECT:

The patient's sexual history puts him at increased risk of tertiary syphilis, a rare cause of arthritis. However, the absence of other signs expected with tertiary syphilis, including cardiac murmur due to aortic valve regurgitation or unsteady gait due to tabes dorsalis, makes this extremely unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient's sexual history puts him at increased risk for contracting sexually transmitted diseases (e.g., C. trachomatis, N. gonorrhea) that could result in reactive arthritis, which can also have an insidious onset and involve the lower extremities. However, the absence of any signs of acute inflammation on examination (e.g., pain, redness, warmth) makes this diagnosis very unlikely.

F) CORRECT:

This patient's history of insulin-dependent diabetes and peripheral neuropathy in a stocking-glove pattern suggests underlying diabetic neuropathy. The findings of unilateral ankle edema and chronic joint destruction without signs of inflammation (e.g., no warmth or redness) are consistent with diabetic arthropathy (Charcot foot), which is thought to be a complication of diabetic neuropathy. Diabetic arthropathy typically is characterized by acute swelling and erythema in the initial stages before progressing to painless joint destruction and bony deformities (most commonly tarsal and metatarsal joints), which can manifest with midfoot collapse and “rocker bottom foot”.
Image Description:

X-ray forefoot (dorsoplantar view) of a patient with diabetes mellitus

There is marked deformity of the second metatarsal head and malalignment at the second and third metatarsal-phalangeal (MTP; green circle) and interphalangeal (IP) joints. The proximal phalanges show lateral subluxation. Additional findings include metatarsus varus and hallux valgus with bunion formation (arrow).
questions.hint: The collapsed midfoot arch in this patient suggests a specific type of joint destruction.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a painless ulcer on the sole of her right foot. There is no history of trauma. She has been dressing the ulcer once daily at home with gauze. She has a 15-year history of poorly-controlled type 1 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Current medications include insulin and lisinopril. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a 2 x 2-cm ulcer on the plantar aspect of the base of the great toe with whitish, loose tissue on the floor of the ulcer and a calloused margin. A blunt metal probe reaches the deep plantar space. Sensation to vibration and light touch is decreased over both feet. Pedal pulses are intact. An x-ray of the right foot shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?

choices.text: Total contact casting of right foot
Sharp surgical debridement of the ulcer
Surgical revascularization of the right foot

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Total contact casting is indicated in the management of neuropathic foot ulcers, as it off-loads the pressure from the wound and facilitates healing. This patient has a neuropathic ulcer, as evidenced by the clinical findings of decreased vibration and light touch sensation in the feet. However, while total contact casting would promote wound healing, this patient requires primary wound care before this treatment can be considered.

B) INCORRECT:

Amputation is reserved for infected diabetic ulcers with life-threatening sepsis (e.g., wet gangrene) or complicated diabetic ulcers that are unlikely to heal despite conservative therapy (e.g., extensive necrosis of the muscles, chronic osteomyelitis that is refractory to treatment, insufficient circulation due to coexistent PAD). This patient has no evidence of sepsis or local infection and has palpable peripheral pulses, which indicates good arterial supply. Thus, conservative therapy would be an appropriate treatment option at this time.

C) INCORRECT:

The frequency of dressing change of a diabetic ulcer depends on the characteristics of the ulcer. A twice- or thrice-daily dressing would benefit an ulcer that is infected or that has a profuse exudate and soaks the dressing. This permits frequent inspection of the wound, removal of dead or infected tissue, prevention of maceration of the surrounding skin, and promotes healing. An ulcer with healthy granulation tissue should be dressed less frequently (once every 2–3 days) to avoid disrupting the healing process. As this patient's ulcer has no evidence of infection, profuse discharge, or granulation tissue, a once-daily dressing, which is already being done, is sufficient. Another intervention to expedite healing is more urgently indicated.

D) INCORRECT:

Intravenous antibiotic therapy would be indicated if there was evidence of secondary infection of the ulcer (e.g., fever, local cellulitis, purulent discharge) or osteomyelitis of the bone underlying the ulcer (e.g., purulent discharge, positive probe-to-bone test, abnormalities on the foot x-ray). As this patient currently has no evidence of any of these conditions, intravenous antibiotic therapy is not required.

E) CORRECT:

Sharp surgical debridement of the slough and calloused margins of this patient's ulcer using a scalpel blade or scissors will promote healing and decrease the risk of bacterial infection.

Peripheral neuropathy screening is a key component of the management of patients with diabetes. Pressure sensation (or protective sensation of the foot) can be tested using the monofilament test, vibration sense is tested using the tuning-fork test, and pain sensation is tested using the pinprick test. Daily self-examination of the feet for evidence of injury or infection is also recommended. These measures help prevent and detect diabetic ulcers.
Image Description:

Well-demarcated ulcerations are visible on the plantar aspect of this patient's left foot

This appearance together with a consistent medical history is suggestive of diabetic foot ulcers, which are likely caused by diabetic polyneuropathy.

F) INCORRECT:

Surgical revascularization is indicated for the management of arterial ulcers that develop in patients with peripheral arterial disease (PAD). Arterial ulcers are typically painful, shallow ulcers with a punched-out edge, and pale granulation tissue on the ulcer floor. These ulcers commonly develop over the toes, malleoli, or the dorsum of the foot, unlike this patient's painless plantar ulcer. In addition, there is no evidence of PAD in this patient, such as claudication pain or absent peripheral pulses. Thus, surgical revascularization is not an appropriate therapy in this patient.
questions.hint: The whitish, loose tissue on the floor of this patient's diabetic foot ulcer is slough that, if left untreated, can predispose to secondary infection of the ulcer and inhibit wound healing.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman comes to the physician because of painless reddening and swelling of her right foot. The swelling of the foot started several months ago, but the redness along with warmth only appeared last week, after a strenuous hike with her husband. She does not recall any recent trauma, fever, or chills. She has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Her mother had rheumatoid arthritis. Current medications include metformin, losartan, and atorvastatin. She has not seen a physician for 1 year. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 78/min, and blood pressure is 144/80 mm Hg. Examination shows a severely swollen, erythematous, right foot and ankle with collapse of the midfoot; range of motion is decreased but not painful. There is no focal tenderness. Peripheral pulses are palpable. Sensation to pinprick, light touch, and vibration is decreased over the soles of both feet. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
14.1 g/dL


Leukocyte count
9500/mm3



Erythrocyte sedimentation rate
22 mm/h


Serum



 Glucose

135 mg/dL


 Uric acid
4.5 mg/dL


An x-ray of the right foot is shown. Which of the following measures is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Smoking is a known risk factor for rheumatoid arthritis (RA), which can manifest with recurrent joint swelling, decreased range of motion, and joint deformities. This patient's positive family history is also a risk factor for developing RA. However, RA typically manifests with symmetrical pain and swelling of metacarpophalangeal and/or proximal interphalangeal joints; unilateral involvement of foot joints is very rare. Furthermore, patients with RA typically have an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate.

B) CORRECT:

Diabetes mellitus is often complicated by vascular and neuropathic changes that most commonly affect the distal extremities. These changes are an important cause of morbidity in patients with diabetes because they usually result in complications like diabetic foot ulcers and foot deformities, including Charcot foot. Regular foot examination should be routinely performed on every patient with diabetes to assess for possible complications (e.g., ulcers, deformities) or possible risk factors for complications (e.g., poor nail care, infections, calluses, inappropriate footwear) and must include inspection, monofilament testing, and assessment of pedal pulses. Regular monofilament testing allows the early detection of diabetic neuropathy and thereby reduces the likelihood of further complications.

C) INCORRECT:

Calcium and vitamin D supplementation might be indicated for osteoporosis prophylaxis, especially in postmenopausal women and older adults, such as this patient. However, calcium and vitamin D supplementation has no role in the prevention of diabetic arthropathy.

D) INCORRECT:

Reducing meat intake is one of the measures to prevent an acute gout flare, which can manifest with redness, swelling, warmth, and decreased range of motion of the affected joint. Furthermore, recurrent gout attacks can result in chronic gouty arthritis, in which degenerative changes similar to those in this patient can be seen on x-ray. However, acute gout flares are typically accompanied by severe acute pain, and affected individuals typically have elevated serum uric acid levels. Moreover, this patient has no history of recurrent gouty arthritis.

E) INCORRECT:

Prophylactic antibiotic therapy is indicated in recurrent cellulitis, which can manifest with tissue swelling, erythema, and warmth. This patient has type 2 diabetes mellitus, which is a known risk factor for recurrent cellulitis. However, cellulitis is associated with pain, tenderness, systemic symptoms (e.g., fever, malaise), and leukocytosis. Moreover, this patient has no history of episodes of cellulitis.
questions.hint: The x-ray shows deformity, malalignment, and severe degenerative changes of the second and third metatarsal heads. These findings, in conjunction with unilateral, painless swelling of the foot and symmetrical decreased sensation in the distal lower extremities in a patient with diabetes mellitus suggest diabetic neuropathic arthropathy, also known as Charcot foot.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of a lesion on the sole of his left foot. He has not sustained any recent trauma. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Medications are insulin, metoprolol, and enalapril. He appears well. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 79/min, and blood pressure is 124/78 mm Hg. Examination shows a 1x1-cm ulcer on the plantar aspect of the left foot near the base of the second toe. The ulcer has well-defined, dry, hyperkeratotic margins and an erythematous base. Pedal pulses are palpable. Sensation to pinprick, light touch, and vibration are decreased over the soles of both feet. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An MRI of the foot can be used to evaluate for osteomyelitis, but the examination findings are equivocal for this diagnosis. An additional step should be performed before an MRI is considered.

B) CORRECT:

The probe-to-bone test is a bedside test used to assess the likelihood of osteomyelitis in patients with diabetic foot ulcers. The test is positive (i.e., osteomyelitis is likely) if the sterile probe inserted into the ulcer contacts bone. Osteomyelitis should be suspected in any patient with an ulcer and one or more of the following features: a positive probe-to-bone test or exposed bone tissue, an ulcer that overlies a bony prominence and has a size > 2 cm2, depth > 3 mm, and/or local signs of infection (e.g., pus, erythematous wound margins, necrotic ulcer base, adjacent sinuses), chronic (≥ 4 weeks) and/or treatment-resistant ulcers, a markedly increased ESR without explanation.

If osteomyelitis is suspected, imaging of the region with the ulcer should be performed. Plain x-ray is typically the initial imaging test of choice but can be unremarkable during the initial phase of osteomyelitis; advanced imaging (e.g., MRI, bone scan) may be warranted in patients with an ulcer for < 2 weeks or in those who have inconclusive radiographic findings. A definitive diagnosis of osteomyelitis is established via characteristic histology findings and a positive culture on bone biopsy.

C) INCORRECT:

A bone scan can be used to evaluate for osteomyelitis but, at this point, the examination findings are equivocal for osteomyelitis. An additional step should be performed before a bone scan is considered.

D) INCORRECT:

A wedge biopsy may be indicated if an atypical etiology of the ulcer is suspected (e.g., malignancy) or if an ulcer does not respond to therapy. This patient presents with characteristic features of a neuropathic ulcer due to diabetes mellitus (ulcer location on a plantar pressure point, palpable pedal pulses, decreased sensation over both feet) and has yet to receive treatment for the lesion. It is therefore not necessary to perform a wedge biopsy at this point.

E) INCORRECT:

A wound swab from a diabetic foot ulcer can be used to detect soft tissue infection. However, most wounds are superficially colonized by a variety of bacteria that are unrelated to the causative pathogen of the infection. Therefore, a deep tissue swab (e.g., from a subcutaneous tissue specimen) is more reliable than a superficial swab for detecting the causative pathogen of soft tissue infection.
questions.hint: This patient has developed a diabetic foot ulcer, which can progress quickly to osteomyelitis.

questions.text:
A 51-year-old man with type 1 diabetes complicated by diabetic neuropathy and nephropathy reports a 2-week history of discomfort in his right great toe. Last week, he noticed a draining area on the toe with tan-colored staining on his sock. Today, he notes that the drainage has increased and has an odor.
On examination, his temperature is 37.1°C, and his other vital signs are within normal limits. There is a large callus overlying the first metatarsophalangeal joint on his sole, with a 2-cm ulceration extending deep into the skin. Approximately 2 cm of erythema and induration surround the ulcer. The patient's peripheral pulses are normal, and his peripheral perfusion does not appear to be compromised.
Introduction of a narrow probe into the ulcer reaches bony resistance. After debridement of necrotic tissue, a 3-view radiograph series of his foot shows soft-tissue swelling but no definitive bony involvement.
In addition to obtaining an MRI of the forefoot, which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Admit to the hospital, and treat with empiric intravenous vancomycin and fluconazole
Initiate home treatment with empiric oral cephalexin and ciprofloxacin
Obtain a wound culture with a swab of the ulcer base in clinic, and initiate oral antibiotics based on the results
Admit to the hospital, and obtain a bone biopsy and culture to guide treatment
Admit to the hospital, and treat with empiric piperacillin-tazobactam

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Given that this patient’s evaluation is consistent with osteomyelitis, the most appropriate management is to admit him to the hospital and obtain a bone biopsy and culture to guide treatment. Empiric therapy for fungal pathogens, such as with fluconazole, is not generally necessary.

B) INCORRECT:

Intravenous antibiotics are typically given for initial therapy of osteomyelitis; thus, oral antibiotics, such as cephalexin, would not be appropriate for this patient. Although empiric therapy is sometimes required, pathogen-directed therapy, guided by bone cultures, should be pursued whenever possible.

C) INCORRECT:

Results of superficial wound cultures correlate poorly with the pathogen responsible for the deep wound. Culture specimens should ideally be obtained from deep infected tissue that does not communicate to the skin surface; a bone biopsy and culture are recommended for directing antibiotic treatment.

D) CORRECT:

The development of foot ulcers in patients with diabetes mellitus is multifactorial; etiologic contributors include impaired blood supply, especially with peripheral artery disease, and neuropathy leading to foot deformities and unrecognized trauma due to reduced sensation. The Wagner classification system can be used to document the severity of the ulcer based on depth, presence of exposed deep structures, infection, and status of distal perfusion.

Diabetic Foot Infections

Infection is a major risk of diabetic foot ulcer and should be promptly evaluated and managed when suspected. Bacterial colonization is common, but infection with bacterial invasion into tissue can lead to the development of cellulitis, osteomyelitis, septic tenosynovitis, septic arthritis, and abscess formation. Diabetic foot infections are one of the most common diabetic complications leading to hospitalization and are a common precipitating event for lower-limb amputation.

Evaluating for Osteomyelitis

When diabetic foot infection is suspected, noninvasive assessment should be performed to determine the adequacy of the peripheral circulation, but the next most important step is to evaluate for the presence of osteomyelitis, as this condition requires longer antibiotic treatment than a simple soft-tissue infection does. If the examiner can probe bone at the base of the ulcer, osteomyelitis is very likely.

Plain radiographs should also be obtained and may show bony abnormalities consistent with osteomyelitis as well as associated findings such as calcified blood vessels and/or evidence of Charcot neuroarthropathy. Radiographs can also show any foreign bodies and gas and can help assess the magnitude of bony involvement.

If the clinical and radiographic evaluation is consistent with osteomyelitis, then the clinician should obtain a bone biopsy for culture to determine the causative pathogen and tailor the antibiotic therapy accordingly. A multidisciplinary approach to the care of these patients is often required, including surgical debridement, revascularization or amputation, and infectious disease consultation to optimize the antibiotic regimen, duration, and route of administration.

In general, specialized imaging such as MRI or bone scintigraphy is more sensitive than plain radiography but is typically needed only if the initial clinical and radiographic evaluation does not adequately rule in or out a diagnosis of osteomyelitis. In addition, these studies are not always specific for infection.

Choosing the Most Appropriate Management in This Case

Given that this patient’s evaluation is consistent with osteomyelitis, the most appropriate management is to admit him to the hospital and obtain a bone biopsy and culture to guide treatment.

This patient does not have an early localized infection that could be managed in the outpatient setting. Inpatient admission is advisable for patients with a deeper ulcer associated with infection that may involve ligament, tendon, joint, bone, or fascia and for patients who have an infection with complicating features (e.g., renal dysfunction, peripheral arterial disease, noncompliance, or lack of social support).

Key learning point: The appropriate management plan for a patient with a moderate diabetic foot infection and osteomyelitis consists of admission to the hospital for bone biopsy and culture and initiation of pathogen-directed intravenous antibiotics.

E) INCORRECT:

Given that this patient’s evaluation is consistent with osteomyelitis, the most appropriate management is to admit him to the hospital and obtain a bone biopsy and culture to guide treatment. Although empiric therapy is sometimes required, pathogen-directed therapy, guided by bone cultures, should be pursued whenever possible.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman reports a 3-day history of redness and swelling on the dorsum of the left foot, associated with some discomfort on weight-bearing. She has a history of morbid obesity and hypothyroidism, as well as a 10-year history of insulin-treated type 2 diabetes complicated by retinopathy and neuropathy.
The patient is afebrile. There is erythema, warmth, and swelling over the dorsum of her left foot, along with pes planus that developed in the past year. She has full range of motion in her ankle and minimal pain with movement and weight-bearing. There is reduced vibratory sensation over the metatarsal heads and diminished ankle reflexes. The skin around her lower extremity is intact, with no ulcerated lesions.
Laboratory testing reveals a leukocyte count of 5300 per mm3 (reference range, 4500–11,000) and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 22 mm/hr (1–25).
Evaluation of the joint aspirate from the tibiotalar joint reveals a leukocyte count of 400 per mm3 and no crystals.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient with long-standing type 2 diabetes who has a collapsed arch and no clear evidence of infection most likely has an arthropathy due to neuropathy (Charcot joint), a form of joint disease that most commonly affects the foot and ankle joints. Patients usually describe some localized pain, although it is often mild in comparison to the deformity, which can be striking on examination and particularly on radiography.

Key learning point: A warm, swollen, and erythematous foot in an afebrile patient with type 2 diabetes, peripheral neuropathy, and a normal erythrocyte sedimentation rate is most consistent with a diagnosis of diabetic neuropathic arthropathy.

B) INCORRECT:

Acute calcium pyrophosphate crystal arthritis (pseudogout) is caused by the deposition of calcium pyrophosphate crystals, most commonly in the knee; the ankle and foot are seldom affected. The absence of crystals or inflammation in the joint aspirate makes this diagnosis unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

In the absence of fever and an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate, an infection such as a septic arthritis, cellulitis, or osteomyelitis is unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

In the absence of fever and an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate, an infection such as a septic arthritis, cellulitis, or osteomyelitis is unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

In the absence of fever and an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate, an infection such as a septic arthritis, cellulitis, or osteomyelitis is unlikely.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man with a history of poorly controlled type 2 diabetes, hypertension, and coronary artery disease is seen for routine follow-up. His current medications are metformin, insulin glargine, lisinopril, metoprolol, and aspirin. He reports a 4-month history of a nonhealing sore on his left foot that has recently become increasingly erythematous with increasing purulence.
On physical examination, he is afebrile and in no acute distress. He has palpable dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses bilaterally. A foul-smelling ulcer, measuring 2 cm by 1 cm, with surrounding erythema is evident on the plantar surface of the foot and is debrided (figure). It is not possible to probe down to bone.
In addition to obtaining imaging, which one of the following next steps is most appropriate in the diagnostic evaluation of this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ankle-brachial indexes and, in some cases, angiography are important in evaluating an arterial cause of ulceration, especially in the absence of palpable pedal pulses; however, in this scenario, the presence of pedal pulses and the location of the ulcer make an arterial cause less likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Surface swab cultures are inadequate because they can reflect superficial contamination or bacterial colonization.

C) INCORRECT:

Blood cultures would be appropriate if the patient had systemic signs of infection.

D) CORRECT:

This patient with poorly controlled type 2 diabetes and palpable pedal pulses most likely has a diabetic neuropathic ulcer, and the purulent drainage and erythema are signs of possible infection.

Osteomyelitis should be suspected in patients with chronic wounds, especially if there is exposed bone or if the clinician can probe to bone. In that setting, imaging is indicated. MRI is the most sensitive and specific imaging modality when osteomyelitis is suspected and is more sensitive than CT. Plain radiographs are less sensitive and specific for osteomyelitis but can be useful in identifying other bone abnormalities, gas formation, and foreign bodies.

In patients with a likely infected chronic diabetic neuropathic ulcer, identifying the causative organism is important to help guide therapy. Deep-tissue culture — obtained via incisional biopsy, punch biopsy, or deep curettage of cutaneous tissue (mostly dermis and subcutaneous fat) after the wound has been cleansed — is the best method to obtain a sample for bacterial culture. Deep-tissue cultures are often obtained in an operative setting.

Key learning point: The most important step in determining the optimal antibiotic treatment for a patient with a neuropathic diabetic ulcer is obtaining a deep-tissue culture.

E) INCORRECT:

Ankle-brachial indexes and, in some cases, angiography are important in evaluating an arterial cause of ulceration, especially in the absence of palpable pedal pulses; however, in this scenario, the presence of pedal pulses and the location of the ulcer make an arterial cause less likely.

questions.text:
A 57-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia presents for evaluation of an ulcer on the plantar aspect of her right foot. She first noticed it 3 weeks ago and estimates that it was <2 cm in diameter at that time. She applied local wound care, including daily wet-to-dry dressings and foot baths, and the ulcer gradually decreased in size. However, one week ago, she developed throbbing pain in her right foot and noticed cream-colored drainage from the ulcer. She has had no fever, chills, night sweats, or loss of appetite.
Her medical record shows a recent glycated hemoglobin value of 8.2% (reference range, 4.3–5.6). Her current medications include metformin 1000 mg twice daily, lisinopril 20 mg daily, and atorvastatin 10 mg daily. She does not have a history of recent antibiotic exposure, residence in a long-term care facility, HIV infection, end-stage kidney disease requiring hemodialysis, or infection or colonization with methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA).
On examination, she has a temperature of 37.5°C, a heart rate of 84 beats per minute, and a blood pressure of 147/85 mm Hg. Her right foot is mildly edematous, and there is a 1-cm plantar ulcer, with ragged edges and foul-smelling pus draining from it, at the proximal aspect of the first metatarsal bone. The wound is surrounded by an area of warm erythema extending 3 cm from the ulcer border. The wound is debrided and explored to a maximum depth of 1 cm, but it cannot be probed to the bone. An MRI of the foot does not show any evidence of osteomyelitis.
The area of erythema surrounding the wound is swabbed for culture, but no organisms are visualized on a Gram stain performed in the office.
Which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Hospital admission with initiation of intravenous vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam
Local wound care with increased frequency of dressing changes (twice daily)

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Diabetic foot infections are diagnosed clinically based on the presence of signs of inflammation (erythema, swelling, warmth, or tenderness), purulent drainage, foul odor, or systemic findings (fever, chills, tachycardia, or hypotension). This patient's infection would be classified as moderately severe, given the description of the wound, the extent of the surrounding erythema (>2 cm), and the absence of fever, tachycardia, and hypotension. In the presence of signs of infection, antibiotic therapy targeted at the most likely pathogens is indicated.

In general, Gram stains and cultures of superficial swabs do not reliably identify the microbial cause of deep infections. Most diabetic foot infections are polymicrobial. Common organisms include beta-hemolytic streptococci (especially Streptococcus agalactiae), methicillin-susceptible Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA), aerobic gram-negative bacilli, and obligate anaerobes. Pseudomonas aeruginosa is less commonly implicated in diabetic foot infections but should be suspected in a macerated wound or if the affected foot has been frequently exposed to water, as in this case. Methicillin-resistant S. aureus (MRSA) should be suspected in the setting of key epidemiologic risk factors (including previous MRSA infection or colonization, recent antibiotic exposure, residence in a long-term care facility, HIV infection, and end-stage kidney disease requiring hemodialysis). This patient does not have any such factors.

The combination of amoxicillin-clavulanate and ciprofloxacin provides adequate empiric coverage for the usual pathogens implicated in moderate-severity diabetic foot infections. It also provides coverage for P. aeruginosa, which is important in this case given the significant water exposure. Of note, amoxicillin-clavulanate treats MSSA but not MRSA, so it is not an appropriate choice if MRSA is suspected. A reasonable alternative in this case would be to combine ciprofloxacin with either a semisynthetic penicillinase-resistant penicillin, such as dicloxacillin, or a second- or third-generation cephalosporin. In all cases, close monitoring for response is critical. The suggested duration of therapy for diabetic foot infections ranges from 1 week to 4 weeks, depending on severity and clinical response.

Key learning point: Empiric antimicrobial therapy for a diabetic foot infection of moderate severity should include coverage for beta-hemolytic streptococci, Staphylococcus aureus (including methicillin-resistant S. aureus if epidemiologic risk factors are present), aerobic gram-negative bacilli (including Pseudomonas aeruginosa if risk factors are present), and anaerobes.

B) INCORRECT:

Clindamycin alone is not appropriate in this case because it does not have activity against several of the organisms that should be empirically covered in this case, including P. aeruginosa.

C) INCORRECT:

The combination of parenteral vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam provides excellent coverage of the likeliest pathogens in the vast majority of diabetic foot infections. However, most moderate-severity infections are localized without clinical evidence of sepsis and can therefore be managed on an outpatient basis with oral antibiotics.

D) INCORRECT:

Linezolid provides excellent coverage of gram-positive organisms, including both MSSA and MRSA, as well as streptococci, which are the usual causative pathogens in milder diabetic foot infections. However, in this particular case, aerobic gram-negative bacilli — P. aeruginosa in particular — and anaerobic organisms are the more important considerations when selecting an empiric antimicrobial regimen.

E) INCORRECT:

Aggressive local wound care alone would not be adequate for this patient. Although such care is an important part of managing diabetic foot wounds and infections, systemic antibiotic therapy is recommended when there is evidence of infection.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 2-month history of a painless wound on her right toe. She has not accessed medical care in over 5 years and has a history of untreated hypertension. Her temperature is 36.9°C, pulse is 80/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 160/100 mm Hg. A photograph of the lesion is provided. There is diffuse hyperpigmentation of the anterior shins. Probe-to-bone testing of the lesion is negative. Sensation to pinprick and light touch is decreased over the soles of both feet. The remainder of the examination is normal. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of her foot lesion?

choices.text: Immune-mediated inflammation of small blood vessels.
Bacterial infiltration into the bone marrow.

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Chronic hyperglycemia leads to nonenzymatic glycation (NEG) of axon proteins, which causes progressive sensorimotor neuropathies, especially of the peripheral nerves. This explains why diabetic foot ulcers are typically painless. Furthermore, NEG causes autonomic neuropathy and vascular disease, both of which contribute to the formation and poor healing of diabetic foot ulcers. Patients with DM should undergo regular screening for neuropathy, which includes assessments of sensation to vibration (using a tuning fork), pressure (using a monofilament test), and pain (using a pinprick test). Strict glycemic control should be maintained in order to prevent diabetic neuropathy and other complications.

NEG of hemoglobin due to chronic hyperglycemia can be assessed by measuring HbA1c percentage. A value ≥ 6.5% is sufficient to diagnose DM, and a value of 5.7–6.4% indicates prediabetes. NEG of the glomerular basement membrane is also common and can lead to renal failure and a progressive decline in kidney function. Screening for proteinuria is therefore recommended for all patients with DM.

Key learning point: Nonenzymatic glycation from chronic hyperglycemia leads to diabetic neuropathy and vascular disease, causing painless foot ulcers and impaired wound healing in diabetes.

B) INCORRECT:

Incompetence of venous valves leads to chronic venous insufficiency (CVI), a condition that can cause cutaneous ulcers and hyperpigmentation of the leg. However, cutaneous ulcers due to CVI are typically painful and develop near the malleoli, whereas this patient has nontender lesions on the digit of the foot. Moreover, CVI does not cause bilaterally decreased sensation of the lower extremities.

C) INCORRECT:

Small vessel vasculitis is seen in patients with thromboangiitis obliterans (TAO), which can manifest in late stages with cutaneous ulcers that are typically localized on the digits. However, TAO usually also manifests with intermittent claudication, Raynaud phenomenon, and/or migratory thrombophlebitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Osteomyelitis can develop as a complication of chronic ulcers, in which skin bacteria infiltrate through the ulcer and into the bone marrow. This condition is especially common in patients with diabetes. However, this patient does not have typical features of osteomyelitis such as a positive probe-to-bone test, fever, or pain at the site of the lesion.

E) INCORRECT:

Peripheral arterial disease (PAD) can occur in patients with diabetes mellitus and can cause cutaneous ulcers as a late manifestation. However, lesions due to PAD are painful, whereas this patient has a history of a painless ulcer. Moreover, other characteristic features of PAD, such as intermittent claudication and diminished pulses are absent.
questions.hint: This patient has several manifestations of diabetes mellitus (DM), including a painless ulcer located at a pressure point, decreased sensation over the soles of the feet, and hyperpigmented skin (due to diabetic dermopathy).

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with a history of arterial hypertension, diabetes, and coronary heart disease presents to the emergency department with a painless ulcer on the plantar surface of his right foot. He reports he discovered it 3 days ago when his wife noticed blood on his sock. Physical examination shows decreased sensation to light touch on both feet. A photograph of the lesion is shown. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While arterial ulcers can occur in patients with diabetes and typically present as punched-out lesions with well-defined borders, they are usually painful. This lesion's painless presentation and the presence of decreased sensation suggest a different etiology.

B) INCORRECT:

Venous ulcers characteristically occur above the ankle in the gaiter region and present as shallow ulcers with irregular borders. This lesion's location over the metatarsal heads and the presence of decreased sensation suggest a different etiology.

C) INCORRECT:

Pyoderma gangrenosum typically presents as rapidly progressive, painful ulcers, often associated with inflammatory bowel disease or other autoimmune conditions. The presentation of this lesion is characteristic of a different etiology.

D) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient demonstrates the classic presentation of a neuropathic diabetic foot ulcer: painless ulceration occurring at a site of repetitive stress (plantar metatarsal head) with evidence of underlying peripheral neuropathy (decreased sensation).

E) INCORRECT:

Basal cell carcinoma typically presents as a slow-growing nodule or plaque on sun-exposed areas and would be an unusual diagnosis for a plantar foot lesion in this clinical context.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with diabetes presents with a 6-week chronic ulcer over the first metatarsal head measuring 3 cm2. Laboratory results show ESR 78 mm/hour and leukocytosis. The patient completed a 10-day course of clindamycin last month with minimal improvement. Examination shows surrounding erythema, warmth, and purulent drainage. Wound cultures are obtained. What is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: Discharge with oral antibiotics and outpatient follow-up
Refer to wound care clinic for outpatient management
Discharge with topical antimicrobials and dressing changes
Perform debridement and reassess in 48 hours
Admit for parenteral antibiotics and MRI of the foot

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient has multiple factors suggesting osteomyelitis, including chronic ulcer duration, large ulcer size (>2 cm2), markedly elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) (>70 mm/hour), treatment-resistant infection, and an ulcer overlying a bony prominence. Outpatient oral antibiotic management is inadequate for suspected osteomyelitis, particularly given this patient's poor response to previous antibiotic therapy.

B) INCORRECT:

Although wound care is important, this patient has signs of severe infection with suspected osteomyelitis, which requires immediate inpatient management rather than outpatient referral. This patient's poor response to previous antibiotics and systemic inflammatory markers indicate the need for urgent intervention.

C) INCORRECT:

Topical antimicrobials are not indicated for the treatment of diabetic foot infections. This patient has systemic signs of infection and suspected osteomyelitis, which requires systemic antibiotic therapy rather than topical treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

Although debridement may be required, delaying antibiotic therapy is inappropriate because of the clinical evidence of severe infection with suspected osteomyelitis. This patient requires immediate admission and parenteral antibiotic therapy.

E) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient meets multiple admission criteria, including chronic ulcer with little response to outpatient antibiotic management and clinical features highly suggestive of osteomyelitis. Chronic duration, large ulcer size, markedly elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), unexplained leukocytosis, location over a bony prominence, and poor response to previous treatment all require inpatient management with parenteral antibiotics and imaging evaluation.

questions.text:
A 63-year-old man presents with a non-healing ulcer on his left foot for the past four weeks. He has a 20-year history of type 2 diabetes. He reports decreased sensation in his toes and thick calluses around the ulcer. Examination shows mild edema, scant hair over the foot, and barely palpable pedal pulses. He is scheduled for surgical debridement of the ulcer.
Which of the following interventions is most appropriate before proceeding?

choices.text: Noninvasive vascular studies to assess arterial flow
Magnetic resonance imaging of the foot

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In diabetic patients with chronic foot ulcers, signs such as hair loss, diminished pedal pulses, and neuropathy suggest compromised arterial blood flow. Noninvasive vascular studies, including the ankle-brachial index and duplex ultrasonography, are crucial to assess peripheral arterial disease. Evaluating arterial supply preoperatively helps identify the need for vascular interventions, optimizing surgical outcomes and promoting wound healing. Vascular insufficiency significantly impacts healing and increases complication risks in diabetic foot wounds.

Key learning point: In patients with diabetes, it is important to assess peripheral circulation by examining peripheral pulses before performing procedures on the foot to ensure adequate blood flow and healing potential.

B) INCORRECT:

Immediate surgical debridement is important for removing necrotic tissue in diabetic foot ulcers. However, signs of peripheral arterial disease, such as barely palpable pedal pulses and scant hair, indicate impaired perfusion. Adequate blood flow is essential for healing, and assessing vascular status before debridement is necessary to avoid exacerbating ischemia.

C) INCORRECT:

Broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotics are indicated for severe infections with signs like erythema, warmth, purulent discharge, or systemic toxicity. This patient lacks such infection indicators, and the focus should be on evaluating vascular status to ensure optimal healing post-debridement.

D) INCORRECT:

Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is used to detect osteomyelitis and soft tissue infections when there is clinical suspicion. This patient shows features of a neuropathic ulcer without signs of deep infection, such as severe bone pain or a positive probe-to-bone test, making MRI unnecessary at this stage.
